Award.AwardTitle: Helium Droplet Spectroscopy of Atmospherically Significant Reaction Intermediates
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) and Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) programs of the Chemistry Division, Professor Gary Douberly of the University of Georgia is using liquid helium droplets to isolate and characterize the intermediates of chemical reactions. Reaction intermediates are difficult to study because they are only present for a short period of time before they react to form more stable molecules. Professor Douberly and his students overcome this long-standing experimental challenge by sequentially adding the individual reactants to liquid helium droplets. In the ultra-cold environment of the helium droplet, which is about 452 degrees Fahrenheit below zero, the reaction intermediates are "frozen out", allowing time for their molecular structures to be observed using laser spectroscopy. This project targets two fundamental chemical reactions that play key roles in the atmosphere, and is thus impacting our understanding of the complex web of chemical reactions associated with air pollution and the formation of small liquid droplets called aerosols.

The first chemical reaction targeted by the project is the oxidation of isoprene, a small molecule that accounts for half of the organic compounds emitted into the atmosphere by plants, and is thus important to our understanding of the troposphere, the lowest portion of the Earth's atmosphere. Isoprene is oxidized by hydroxyl radicals, which are added to the helium droplets, and infrared spectroscopy is used to probe the branching of the reaction into the various intermediates. The intermediates are then reacted with oxygen to produce the associated hydroxyperoxy radicals, which are also studied using infrared techniques. The second aim of the project centers on identifying the minimum number of water molecules that are needed to observed the spontaneous transfer of a proton from sulfuric acid to water, a process that is central to the nucleation of atmospheric aerosol particles. This process is studied through the sequential addition of water molecules to helium droplets containing a single sulfuric acid molecule. Species selective spectroscopy is then used to determine the structures of these small acid-water clusters and identify the onset of proton loss from the acid. Analogous measurements probe the effect of ammonia (and other amines) on reducing the critical cluster size necessary for spontaneous proton transfer. In addition to providing important insight into fundamental atmospheric processes, the project provides opportunities for student training, mentoring, and the integration of laboratory research with undergraduate-centered educational activities.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The vibrational spectra of organic molecules are complicated by the presence of pervasive anharmonic resonances in the X-H bond stretch region. This deviation from simple harmonic behavior can be accounted for via theoretical methods that start from a harmonic approximation and then account for anharmonicity with increasing levels of sophistication. We have employed cold, helium droplets as a matrix for recording high-quality, fully vibrationally resolved, infrared spectra of unsaturated hydrocarbons, such as isoprene and propene. Moreover, we have employed gas-phase ion spectroscopic techniques to record vibrational spectra of the exotic HO4+ molecular ion (HOOOO+). The interpretation of the vibrational spectra related to this collection of molecular systems is challenging due vibrational anharmonicity, including a significant number of connected resonances. We have employed second-order vibrational perturbation theory with resonances (VPT2+K) to analyze and assign the vibrational spectra of the aforementioned molecular systems. In doing so, we have optimized the theory to be used with large effective Hamiltonian treatments of the resonant interactions, which involves the careful consideration of systems of connected resonances. We have published a tutorial review of the VPT2+K method for the broader molecular spectroscopy community.

Helium droplets were also used to probe the sequential capture of isoprene and the hydroxyl radical (OH). Sequential capture of isoprene and OH by a helium droplet leads to reaction. We find no evidence for the kinetic trapping of van der Waals complexes behind small barriers in the entrance channel to the reaction. This is despite the fact that previous theoretical studies predicted such barriers.

 

Broader Impacts

Two graduate students provided the majority of effort on this project. Gregory Pullen earned his Ph.D in May 2020, and he is now a Post-doc in Heather Lewandowski's lab at JILA, University of Colorado. Peter Franke earned his Ph.D in July 2020 and he is now a Post-doc in John Stanton's group at the University of Florida.

The vibrational spectroscopic study of propene was carried out in collaboration with Yuan-Pern Lee at the National Chiao Tung University in Taiwan. Yuan-Pern Lee is a leader in the field of Chemical Physics, and through this initial interaction, we are now involved in a full-scale collaboration on the spectroscopy of molecules in helium droplets and solid para-Hydrogen, both of which are considered "quantum matrices". The solid para-hydrogen work is done in Taiwan, and the helium droplet work is done in the Douberly lab at the University of Georgia.

In addition to the vibrational spectroscopic study of isoprene, we carried out a high-level theoretical study of isoprene's thermochemistry. The results from this study are being used as part of an active learning module in the junior-level physical chemistry course at the University of Georgia.


Last Modified: 11/18/2020
Modified by: Gary E Douberly
